item.title: Talks on Russia-Ukraine War Enter 2nd Day in Geneva
item.content:encoded: The discussions in Geneva were expected to focus on territorial issues, a major sticking point, but the short duration suggests major progress was not made.

item.title: Nine Skiers Still Missing After Lake Tahoe Avalanche
item.content:encoded: The avalanche struck a guided backcountry skiing group near Truckee, Calif., near the end of a multiday trip, officials said. Six skiers have been rescued.

item.title: An Architect of Virginia’s Redistricting Will Run for a New Seat Himself
item.content:encoded: Dan Helmer, a Democratic state lawmaker, played a key role in putting redrawn congressional maps before state voters.

item.title: Democrats Plan to Counter Trump’s Speech to Congress With Rally
item.content:encoded: The House Democratic leader has asked rank-and-file members to sit quietly at the speech or skip it altogether, wary of creating a distraction.

item.title: The A.I. Disruption Has Arrived, and It Sure Is Fun
item.content:encoded: We’re entering a new renaissance of software development. We should all be excited, despite the uncertainties that lie ahead.

item.title: A Downtown Vibe Comes to Broadway This Spring
item.content:encoded: Without the usual flood of new musicals, the playwrights of works like “Becky Shaw,” “Dog Day Afternoon” and “Giant” are getting a chance to shine.

item.title: What to See in NYC This Spring: Broadway Shows, Concerts and More
item.content:encoded: Onstage, “Cats: The Jellicle Ball” and Adrien Brody in “The Fear of 13.” Plus: Cardi B goes on tour, Lise Davidsen takes on Isolde at the Met, 100 years of Martha Graham and more.

item.title: ‘Brokeback Mountain,’ ‘Black Swan’ and 14 More Plays and Musicals to See This Spring
item.content:encoded: Across the country, a flurry of theater productions, including “Black Swan” and “The Lunchbox,” are mining the movies for material.

item.title: Methane Hunters Track Swamp Gas That Is Driving Climate Warming
item.content:encoded: Methane emissions from wetlands are rising faster than those from industrial sources, prompting concerns about a climate feedback loop.

item.title: Democrats Win in Texas With Candidates Like Taylor Rehmet
item.content:encoded: A shock Democratic victory in a Texas special election shows what the party needs to do to win more there — and many other places, too.

item.title: What to Know About How Redistricting Is Different in the U.S.
item.content:encoded: In the battle for Congress, redistricting has become all the rage in America. Other nations have guardrails in place to avoid the same situation.

item.title: How Jesse Jackson Took King’s Civil Rights Movement to Company Doorsteps
item.content:encoded: Mr. Jackson was critical to Martin Luther King Jr.’s quest to transform a fight for equality in the South to a national movement for economic and social justice.

item.title: A New Concern About Weight Loss Drugs: What if They Work Too Well?
item.content:encoded: Some patients in a clinical trial of one new drug lost so much weight that they became concerned and dropped out.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Finds a Place to File CBS’s Surprise Statement
item.content:encoded: “I don’t even know what to do with this,” Colbert said about the network’s news release on a scrapped interview with a Democratic politician, before putting the paper in a dog waste bag.

item.title: A Police Parking Lot in East Harlem Will Become Affordable Housing
item.content:encoded: The project is the latest example of a push by New York City to build homes on land it owns. The building will be 100 percent affordable, officials say.

item.title: Viral Videos Helped Mamdani Win. Can They Help Him Govern?
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, who won over voters with his approach to social media, is using the same strategy to try to connect City Hall to all New Yorkers.

item.title: Alberto Tomba Was an ’80s and ’90s Icon. The Olympics Have Brought Him Back.
item.content:encoded: Nicknamed “Tomba la Bomba,” the Italian skier was a global superstar before he drifted from the limelight. Decades later, the Winter Games have given him a new platform.

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.content:encoded: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.content:encoded: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.

item.title: A Road Trip from Kandahar to Kabul on Highway 1 in Afghanistan
item.content:encoded: Life and business are back along a road once defined by war damage. But even with improved security, Afghans are desperate for jobs and development.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.content:encoded: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.content:encoded: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.

item.title: Manhattan Hospital Ends Medical Treatment for Transgender Youth
item.content:encoded: NYU Langone Health cited the “current regulatory environment” in its decision to discontinue its gender medicine program for minors.

item.title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
item.content:encoded: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.

item.title: Mamdani Threatens 9.5% Property Tax Increase if Wealth Tax Is Not Passed
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said his proposal to raise New York City property taxes was a “last resort” to close a budget gap.

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.content:encoded: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”

item.title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
item.content:encoded: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.

item.title: 4 Dead in Colorado Crash as Strong Winds Kick Up Wildfire Warnings
item.content:encoded: High winds were fueling the risk of wildfires across the Southwest and the Plains, and an Oklahoma town faced a mandatory evacuation. Officials said the weather had caused a deadly pileup in Colorado.

item.title: How a Stray Quote of Jesse Jackson’s Led to a Rupture Between Black and Jewish Voters
item.content:encoded: The candidate’s reference to New York as “Hymietown” helped tank his 1984 presidential campaign and eroded a longstanding alliance.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.

item.title: California Wealth Tax Opponents Intensify Efforts Before Bernie Sanders Visit
item.content:encoded: The opponents’ latest moves include online ads tied to Gov. Gavin Newsom, a crypto-related push to raise money and competing ballot measures.

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Death Arrives at a Crucial Moment for Black Political Power
item.content:encoded: There are more Black senators than ever before, but a major Supreme Court ruling could reduce Black representation in the House.

item.title: Republicans, Braced for Losses, Push More Voting Restrictions in Congress
item.content:encoded: Legislation that would require proof of citizenship to register to vote was only the beginning as the G.O.P. presses to sharply limit voting in line with President Trump’s false claims of widespread fraud.

item.title: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
item.content:encoded: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.

item.title: Are you a medical provider who has worked in an ICE detention facility? We want to hear from you.
item.content:encoded: We want to get a better picture of what medical care for immigrants in detention is like.

item.title: When Did Chicken Become the Most Expensive Thing on the Menu?
item.content:encoded: The once-humble plate of poultry has been elevated to luxury status, with prices hitting $50 or more.

item.title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
item.content:encoded: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.

item.title: Bayer Agrees to Pay $7.25 Billion to Settle Roundup Lawsuits
item.content:encoded: The agreement, which still faces legal hurdles, would cover current and future claims that the weedkiller caused non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

item.title: Warner Bros. Discovery Restarts Deal Talks With Paramount
item.content:encoded: Paramount’s takeover bid was rejected in favor of Netflix, which wanted only the streaming and studio businesses. Paramount said it would pay more if negotiations were reopened.

item.title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
item.content:encoded: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.

item.title: GQ Names Adam Baidawi as Its Top Editor
item.content:encoded: Mr. Baidawi, 35, replaces the magazine’s longtime editor Will Welch. He says he wants the magazine to be a “North Star of masculinity.”

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.content:encoded: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.content:encoded: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.

item.title: Paramount’s New Chance to Win Over Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: The takeover battle took a new turn on Tuesday as Warner Bros. Discovery reopened talks with its rebuffed suitor. But big questions still remain.

item.title: Trump Sought Vast Budget Cuts. Congress Granted Few.
item.content:encoded: In a series of deals over the past three months, lawmakers rejected some of the president’s most aggressive attempts to whittle down the government.

item.title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
item.content:encoded: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.

item.title: How the H-1B Visa Debate Is Driving a Wave of Racism Against South Asians
item.content:encoded: A dispute over the impact of H-1B visas on U.S. workers has been overshadowed by racist rhetoric, with troubling echoes of the great replacement conspiracy theory.

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.

item.title: The Quiet Architect of Trump’s Global Trade War
item.content:encoded: Jamieson Greer, a low-key lawyer from a working-class background, is rewriting the rules of the global economy at the president’s behest.

item.title: How a Trump Tax Break Rescued Horse Racing
item.content:encoded: Owners spent nearly $1.5 billion last year on racehorses, a big increase over 2024. A new tax provision allows them to immediately deduct the full cost of the purchase.

item.title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
item.content:encoded: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.content:encoded: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.

item.title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
item.content:encoded: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.

item.title: Software? No Way. We’re an A.I. Company Now!
item.content:encoded: As their stocks tank, software makers are rebranding themselves as A.I. innovators. Sparkle emojis are everywhere, but some efforts have been more successful than others.

item.title: Will 2026 Be the Year of the ‘Soonicorn’?
item.content:encoded: As venture capital funding pours into start-ups large and small, more firms are pitching themselves as the next big thing.

item.title: What C.E.O.s Are Worried About
item.content:encoded: Fractured politics, disruptive technologies and a distrust in institutions are making it harder to focus on the traditional tasks of growing sales and profits.

item.title: T.S.A. Workers Brace for Another Shutdown They Didn’t Cause
item.content:encoded: As Congress leaves town without funding their department, airport security officers wonder, “How many more times am I going to be able to do this?”

item.title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
item.content:encoded: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.

item.title: The Hidden Number Driving U.S. Job Growth
item.content:encoded: After a year of just 181,000 new jobs, January’s 131,000 increase in the U.S. workforce was surprisingly positive. Ben Casselman, The New York Times’ chief economic correspondent, explains the numbers.

item.title: Meta Plans to Add Facial Recognition Technology to Its Smart Glasses
item.content:encoded: In an internal memo last year, Meta said the political tumult in the United States would distract critics from the feature’s release.

item.title: How ICE Is Pushing Tech Companies to Identify Protesters
item.content:encoded: The DHS is flooding social media companies with administrative subpoenas to identify accounts that are protesting ICE. Social media companies have pushed back but are largely complying. Our tech reporter, Sheera Frenkel, explains.

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.content:encoded: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.

item.title: Can You Rely on A.I. to Translate Love?
item.content:encoded: A.I. translation has become a huge industry, but how accurate is it? Our tech reporter, Kashmir Hill, explores its successes and failures through a couple who relies on of A.I. translation to communicate.

item.title: The 2026 Milan Olympics Has Its Eyes on Grana Padano
item.content:encoded: Grana Padano cheese is trying to capture some of the international spotlight on Italy, appearing on billboards and social media — and in high-protein muffins for athletes.

item.title: Sick Detainees Describe Poor Care at CoreCivic ICE Facilities
item.content:encoded: Problems at detention centers operated by CoreCivic extend far beyond recent measles outbreaks.

item.title: How A.I. Salaries Are Causing Couples to Rethink Money in Relationships
item.content:encoded: The artificial intelligence frenzy is creating personal fortunes rarely seen in modern technology and changing people’s attitudes about fairness and money in relationships.

item.title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
item.content:encoded: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.content:encoded: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.

item.title: White House Sees Win After 2 Strong Economic Reports
item.content:encoded: Solid jobs data and a soft inflation reading for January are welcome news for President Trump. But the bigger economic picture is less encouraging.

item.title: Christie’s to Auction 3 of Agnes Gund’s Art Jewels
item.content:encoded: A Rothko, a Twombly and a Surrealist box with a Medici princess by Joseph Cornell are estimated to sell for $145 million.

item.title: U.S. Inflation Eased at Start of the Year
item.content:encoded: The Consumer Price Index fell in January to 2.4 percent from 2.7 percent a month

item.title: Bessent Pushes Senate on Fed Confirmation Amid Backlash Over Criminal Inquiry
item.content:encoded: President Trump’s effort to get Kevin M. Warsh confirmed as the next Federal Reserve chair has been complicated by a criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Trying to Cut Costs? Start With Your Phone, Internet and Streaming Bills.
item.content:encoded: It’s cold outside — and a fine time to look over your bills and see where you can save.

item.title: Crises Everywhere, but the Markets Don’t Seem to Mind
item.content:encoded: Stocks have prospered while the world has plunged into disorder, an economist says. “Keep calm and carry on” may be the best investors can do.

item.title: More Epstein Fallout for Goldman Sachs, DP World and Beyond
item.content:encoded: The Wall Street giant’s top lawyer, whose ties to Jeffrey Epstein had raised questions at the firm, has resigned. Other corporate leaders are also facing blowback.

item.title: Another Government Shutdown? Here’s What Travelers Should Know.
item.content:encoded: It was not immediately clear whether passengers would face delays at airport security checkpoints in the coming days if a government shutdown does occur.

item.title: Conspiracy Theories Only Flourish With More Epstein Evidence
item.content:encoded: The dump of millions of documents has fueled a new wave of speculation, A.I.-generated hoaxes and foreign disinformation.

item.title: Crab Heist Puts Spotlight on Surge of Cargo Thefts
item.content:encoded: Stolen food and beverages, which are easier to offload than costly electronics, are driving an overall spike in cargo crimes, truckers, insurers and other experts say.
